member.name: T:OnionSeed.Data.Decorators.AsyncCommandServiceParallelTap`2
member.summary: Decorates an , mirroring commands to a secondary, "tap" .
member.remarks:
This decorator functions like a parallel network tap: commands are executed against the inner command service and the tap command service at the same time. This can be more performant than the regular, sequential type of tap; but it is also inherently riskier because if an exception is thrown from either command service, they can become out-of-sync.
Any values returned or exceptions thrown from the tap command service are ignored.
This essentially allows for the creation of a duplicate copy of the data, and is intended to be used for things like caching, backup, or reporting.

member.name: M:OnionSeed.Data.Decorators.AsyncCommandServiceParallelTap`2.#ctor(OnionSeed.Data.IAsyncCommandService{`0,`1},OnionSeed.Data.IAsyncCommandService{`0,`1})
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The to be decorated.
The tap , where commands will be duplicated.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The to be decorated.
The tap , where commands will be duplicated.
The logger where tap exceptions should be written.

member.name: P:OnionSeed.Data.Decorators.AsyncCommandServiceParallelTap`2.Logger

member.name: T:OnionSeed.Data.Decorators.AsyncCommandServiceTap`2
member.summary: Decorates an , mirroring commands to a secondary, "tap" .
member.remarks:
This decorator functions like a network tap: commands are executed first against the inner command service; if they succeed, they are then executed against the tap command service as well.
Any values returned or exceptions thrown from the tap command service are ignored.
This essentially allows for the creation of a duplicate copy of the data, and is intended to be used for things like caching, backup, or reporting.

member.name: T:OnionSeed.Data.Decorators.AsyncRepositoryParallelTap`2
member.summary: Decorates an , mirroring commands to a secondary, "tap" .
member.remarks:
This decorator functions like a parallel network tap: commands are executed against the inner repository and the tap repository at the same time. This can be more performant than the regular, sequential type of tap; but it is also inherently riskier because if an exception is thrown from either repository, they can become out-of-sync.
Any values returned or exceptions thrown from the tap repository are ignored.
This essentially allows for the creation of a duplicate copy of the data, and is intended to be used for things like caching, backup, or reporting.

This decorator functions like a network tap: commands are executed first against the inner repository; if they succeed, they are then executed against the tap repository as well.
Any values returned or exceptions thrown from the tap repository are ignored.
This essentially allows for the creation of a duplicate copy of the data, and is intended to be used for things like caching, backup, or reporting.

member.summary: Gets a reference to the handler that will be called when an exception is caught.

member.name: T:OnionSeed.Data.Decorators.AsyncUnitOfWorkParallelTap
member.summary: Decorates an , mirroring commands to a secondary, "tap" .
member.remarks:
This decorator functions like a parallel network tap: commands are executed against the inner unit of work and the tap unit of work at the same time. This can be more performant than the regular, sequential type of tap; but it is also inherently riskier because if an exception is thrown from either unit of work, they can become out-of-sync.
Any values returned or exceptions thrown from the tap unit of work are ignored.
This essentially allows for the creation of a duplicate copy of the data, and is intended to be used for things like caching, backup, or reporting.

member.name: M:OnionSeed.Data.Decorators.AsyncUnitOfWorkParallelTap.#ctor(OnionSeed.Data.IAsyncUnitOfWork,OnionSeed.Data.IAsyncUnitOfWork)

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The to be decorated.

The logger where tap exceptions should be written.

This decorator functions like a network tap: commands are executed first against the inner unit of work; if they succeed, they are then executed against the tap unit of work as well.
Any values returned or exceptions thrown from the tap unit of work are ignored.
This essentially allows for the creation of a duplicate copy of the data, and is intended to be used for things like caching, backup, or reporting.

member.name: T:OnionSeed.Data.IEntity`1
member.summary: Defines an object that is not fundamentally identified by its attributes, but rather by a unique identity value.
member.typeparam: The type of the unique identity value.
member.remarks: Entities are not defined primarily by their attributes. They represent a thread of identity that runs through time and often across distinct representations. Sometimes an entity must be matched with another entity even though their attributes differ. Sometimes an entity must be distinguished from other entities even though their attributes are the same. Mistaken identity in these cases can lead to data corruption; thus, a unique identity value is created for the entity so it can be tracked regardless of the state of its attributes.

member.name: P:OnionSeed.Data.IEntity`1.Id
member.summary: Gets the unique identity value.

member.returns: An enumeration of all entities in the data store.

member.exception: The specified unique identity value does not exist in the data store.
